>Lots of good stuff for crawler improvements or further discussion! Comment=
s
>below...
>
>--- In  <mailto:archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com>
archive-cra=
wler@yahoogroups.com, "Kristinn Sigurdsson" < <mailto:kris@a>
kris@a...> wr=
ote:
>> Some of this is posted here to get some discussion, other bits are =
mostly
>> pointed at the boys at the Archive. Basically, this is a mixed ba=
g.
>> 
>> Remaining time
>> 
>> This feature is of negligible use and is mo=
re likely to confuse than
inform
>> users. The time estimate is only going =
to give a reasonable figure if
there
>> is only one host left (or several h=
osts with a similar number of
documents)
>> and we're already done with the=
 'discovery' phase. This may be of use
>> towards the end of some focused c=
rawls, but generally this is of little
>> value. Since this value is almost=
 always wrong I believe that it is far
more
>> likely to confuse users. I a=
lso find it annoying to have another time
>> counter as I occasionally get =
it mixed up when I'm looking up the
duration
>> of the crawl, but that's a =
lesser issue.
>> 
>> Unless the estimate can be improved significantly (and=
 this requires
taking
>> into account the number of queues and their relati=
ve sizes and the
>> politeness restrictions for anything approaching a reas=
onable estimate) I
>> vote to remove this feature.
>
>I agree that at its c=
urrent level of accuracy, it causes more confusion
>than convenience. But I=
'd very much like to have a 'best guess' of time
>remaining.
>
>As you note=
, this would require more sophisticated estimate calculations
>
>Some ideas=
:
>
>  - Track rates of both URI discovery and completion, and the change
>=
    in these rates over time. Early in any crawl, and for some broad
>    c=
rawls, these rates might imply a crawl that never finishes, or
>    a estim=
ate that's wildly off. In such cases, an estimate could
>    be withheld, o=
r giant 'error bars' indicated ("5 days +/- 1 year").
>    However, later i=
n the crawl, especially after the rate of completion
>    has exceeded the =
rate of discovery, this method would likely be
>    fairly accurate, even w=
ithout considering individual queues.
>
>  - Do the same, per each queue. I=
f all queues are active, the predicted
>    time of finish is the latest pr=
edicted time for any single queue.
>    If queues spend time rotating in an=
d out of activity, some other
>    estimate inflator will have to be applie=
d. Fringe benefit: such
>    per-queue estimates could be used to prioritiz=
e queues that will
>    cannot afford to be out-of-cycle, Confounding facto=
r: queue 'total
>    budgets' or operator intervention will often truncate =
exactly the
>    largest/longest queues because they're deep into chaff/jun=
k. But
>    then again: viewing a ranked report of queues based on longest-=

>    expected-time-of-finish could be very valuable for the operator,
>   =
 even moreso than raw queue size. (Projected times would take into
>    acc=
ount historical responsiveness and discovery rates at server.)
>
>Since I'd=
 like to see someone delve deeper into this, even if we don't
>get a chance=
 to at the IA, I'd like to keep the flawed reading visible,
>properly discl=
aimered, as an advertisement for needed work.
>
>So how about we move it fu=
rther down in the console and label it "naive
>estimate" or some such? 
 
S=
o, we're going to pass this responsibility to the Frontier? I don't see
thi=
s working any other way. This would allow the ARFrontier to simply state
'n=
ever going to finish' (which by definition it never should).
 
>> Include a=
ctual memory used in the progress-statistics.log instead of or
in
>> additi=
on to current heap size.
>> 
>> Actual memory used is of much greater inter=
est, especially when looking
>> through the log to see memory usage trends.=

>
>I made an RFE for this last week:
>
>  add 'memory used' to progress-st=
atistics.log
>
<http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=3Ddetail&aid=
=3D1204644&group_id=3D7
3833&atid=3D539102>
http://sourceforge.net/tracker/=
index.php?func=3Ddetail&aid=3D1204644&group_id=3D73
833&atid=3D539102 
 
I'=
ll take a look at this one. See issue for more.
 
>
>> Default Bdb cache pe=
rcent to something modest, like 35-40% (OOM errors)
>> 
>> The AR module en=
countered some issues with the default setting. I'm not
>> going to vote fo=
r any one value, but I suggest that crawls should always
>> retain a good c=
hunk of memory after the Bdb cache grows to its maximum
>> allowed size.
>
=
>I believe the BDB default is 60%. On your machine, how much RAM is
availab=
le,
>how much heap do you assign Java, and what cache percent did you settl=
e on
>to resolve your issues? 
 
Ok, this one falls under the heading of no=
t having had a lot of thought. 
The ARFrontier was running into trouble (ev=
en with +1GB) when Bdb was set to
default. A crawl with Bdb cache percent s=
everely reduced fixed that. I'm
unsure as to what the appropriate level sho=
uld be.
 
I'm going to amend my suggestion. Lets explicitly set the Bdb cac=
he percent
to 60% in our configurations (that way people will know how much=
 it is going
to take and can better decide if it should be modified).
 
We =
should also add a 'default AR' profile where the cache percent is
lowered.
=
 
>
>> Get rid of the recovery journal in favor of decent crash resistance
=
>> via Bdb 
>> 
>> This is a bigger issue (and I know it's something you gu=
ys want to
>> do). The
>> recovery journal has never (for me) worked as a c=
rash recovery tool.
>> The AR
>> frontier is able to reconstruct itself bas=
ed on its databases without any
>> trouble. If done right, resuming a crawl=
 could be done in a matter of
>> seconds, instead of hours (or days). I'd v=
ote to make this the #1
priority
>> for 1.6!
>
>It is a top priority. The r=
ecovery journal will stay around for a while as
>an optional backup/debuggi=
ng aid/adjunct to checkpoint-based recoveries. 
 
To clarify, I don't mind =
having the recovery journal around. I just REALLY
would like to see a reaso=
nable crash recovery tool in Heritrix. Glad to see
that it is a priority.
 =

Using Bdb it should be possible to rely solely on their crash recovery
too=
ls. The only downside is that we need to ensure that we can (at any time)
r=
ebuild the Frontier from the databases, preferably without having to
iterat=
e through all their items as the AR Frontier currently does. This
means sto=
ring all sorts of rapidly changing data in a database.
 
>
>> Allow frontie=
rs to provide 'servlets' that enables more detailed
>> monitoring
>> and co=
ntrol.
>> 
>> I don't really care how it's done, but we need to allow modul=
es,
>> especially
>> (or even exclusively) Frontiers, need to have customiz=
ed control pages!
>
>Agreed. Perhaps these should be packagable as self-con=
tained WARs that
>can be dropped into the current or future crawler UIs at =
specific paths. 
 
Like I said, I don't care how we accomplish this, it jus=
t NEEDS to happen.
This would also allow us to drop the whole 'Inspect Fron=
tier' bit in favor
of custom built solutions. But more importantly, we coul=
d add all sorts of
controls for Frontiers, such as decent queue manipulatio=
n/inspection that
are currently impossible without narrowing the Frontier i=
nterface.
 
>
>> Display data, 4GB should be 4.442GB etc.
>> 
>> Need to im=
prove how data amounts are condensed, currently the jump from
>> 4095MB to =
4GB lacks granularity. I'd be happy to fix this if we could
>> agree
>> on =
exactly how things are supposed to be. My suggestion: show four
>> characte=
rs. So we'd go from 4095 MB to 4GB and then 4.001GB etc. when
>> we hit
>> =
40GB we go to 40.01 etc. same for the move from B to KB and KB to MB
>> 
>>=
 Additionally, we could have a mouse-over pop up the exact number of
bytes.=

>
>My preference:
>  - always at least 3 significant figures, up to 4 when=
 significand is an
integer
>  - use largest unit that results in a leading =
digit >=3D 1
>
>Examples:
>
>  4.23K
>  1023K
>  1.00M
>  57.3M
>  789M
>  =
1001M
>  1.10G
>  27.2G
>  989G
>  1019G
>  1.27P
>  etc. 
 
Fine with me. =
I'll take a look at this.
 
>
>We should either be pedantic and use 'KiB', =
'MiB', 'GiB', 'PiB' -- or
strategically
>vague like Gnu tools and use just =
'K', 'M', 'G', 'P'. 
 
We've adhered to B meaning bytes (as in 1024 is a ba=
se unit) and b means
bits (with 1000 as a base unit). So 1 KB is 1024 B etc=
. I don't see any
reason to change this. But if adding an 'i' makes people =
more comfortable, I
don't have a problem with it. My concern is that the Ki=
B notation is not all
that commonly used and may be confusing.
 
>
>A mouse=
over in web readouts with exact byte counts would be a nice touch. 
 
This =
is more difficult as it can't be done in a single, central, location. 
 
>
=
>> Default log lines to show be 40 instead of 50
>> 
>> A bit of a nit-pick=
. I've got a screen running at 1024 lines of vertical
>> resolution and 40 =
lines fill up my screen. Since not many users are
likely
>> to have higher =
resolution (in fact I'd expect the average to be lower) I
>> suggest we ame=
nd the default value to 40 (or possibly 35).
>
>I would much prefer it to b=
e significantly larger; I don't mind scrolling
>to get more info, compared =
to forcing a reload with new paramters.
>
>If the problem is that the last =
few lines are of most interest in 'tail'
>views, we could:
>  - target an #=
anchor near the bottom
>  - make the default different for 'tail' views tha=
n in others, where
>    quantity of info in one fetch is more interesting 
=
 
This sounds like the best solution, but requires a significant change to =
how
the log page works.
 
>  - (most radical idea) adopt bloggish display: =
most recent on top,
>    even though raw file on disk is in the opposite or=
der 
 
Tricky to implement and counter intuative in my opinion.
 
Alternati=
ve solution: Have changes to the number of lines displayed be more
durable =
(writing to cookie probably). We could then keep 50 as the factory
default.=

 
>
>> Link from help to /help/regexpr.jsp
>> 
>> I find this page invalua=
ble when adding new regular expressions,
especially
>> to crawls in progres=
s. Lets you double check those reg.expr. using the
same
>> interpreter. The=
 page has been available for awhile, but either the link
was
>> dropped or =
it never existed. Either way, a link should be added to the
>> help page.
>=

>Great idea, please add at your leisure! 
 
Done.
 
>
>> Cost assignment o=
n -5000/-5001
>> 
>> More of a question, do URIs that return with -500X 'co=
st' anything? I'd
>> suggest that they shouldn't. After all, they aren't ac=
tually crawled. 
>
>This would require a refund of cost deducted, since cos=
ts are currently
>applied at the moment an URL comes off its queue. Could y=
ou file a bug
>with an example of how this current behavior has caused a pr=
oblem or
>inconvenience in a crawl? 
 
Here is the thing, once a large craw=
l has been under way for awhile, I
inevitably need to drop in some new filt=
ers to eliminate some junk. These
URIs all wind up with a -500X.
 
If I'm u=
sing a budgeted hold queues, this means that all the -500Xs will be
counted=
 against the queue, slowing its process. -500X take very little time
to pro=
cess after all and the queue is quickly made inactive. Other queues
however=
 still take their usual amount of time. Basically it temporarily
starves (o=
r at least limits) the queue. Additionally (and this isn't a
factor for me)=
 if a queue has a max total budget, do we really want these to
count agains=
t it (probably no negative value URIs should). I'll add a bug
report on thi=
s as you suggest. 
 
>
>> HostnameQueueAssignmentPolicy attaches the port n=
umber to the hostname
>> 
>> Is this really sensible considering that these=
 are used as the basic
>> politeness units. Different ports, same server. I=
'd think we'd want to
>> handle it all the same way.
>
>On the other hand, =
different ports/same host could quite possibly be a
>different 'server' in =
the sense of an independent process whose
reachability
>is not correlated w=
ith other ports on the same machine. Essentially, a
>queue blocks until the=
 top item on it succeeds or has exceeded its
>retries. What if that item is=
 failing repeatedly against a
(no-longer-running)
>server on a nonstandard =
port, while other URLs that would succeed against
>the standard port are st=
uck behind it?
>
>We could offer both kinds of queue-assignment policy. I t=
hink the
>per-port distinction may have been important in a previous Fronti=
er
>but beside the 'stuck behind' problem I just mentioned, all URLs on
>th=
e same hostname could be coalesced in the BdbFrontier. 
 
What we really ne=
ed is for the queue assignment policy to be configurable.
This isn't possib=
le with how things are set up today. The queue assignment
policy would need=
 to be a sub-module.
 
This lead me to thinking. We need a way for modules =
to specify that a
submodule is supposed to be plugged in 'here'. That is, t=
here should be a
place holder type for a sub-module. It would accept the 'b=
ase' class for the
module (such as Filter or the Frontier interface) and th=
e UI would use it's
name to lookup the associated .options file.
 
I know t=
his is a little tricky, but if done right we would effectively
enable modul=
es to declare any types of submodules. The whole business of
having to hard=
 code the sub-modules page to handle the few different types
that we ARE su=
pporting, would be eliminated. The placeholder type could come
in an additi=
onal flavor, List.
 
Actually, if done right, we could drop the whole Modul=
e/SubModule thing and
just have modules that plug into the CrawlOrder or ot=
her modules already on
the CrawlOrder, but I think that might lead to a con=
fusing UI.
 
>
>> Daily reports? Detailed look at the crawl, printed to a f=
ile daily? 
>> 
>> I was thinking that it might be nice to add a 'Daily rep=
ort' feature
>> to the
>> StatisticsTracker. It would generate a (new) repo=
rt file at a
>> specified time
>> each day. Information regarding the numbe=
r of URIs, amount of data,
>> bandwidth usage etc. would be printed, giving=
 a nice summary on the
>> progress
>> so far.
>
>Very good idea; it would a=
lso be natural to mail this report somewhere.
>File an RFE? 
 
http://sourc=
eforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=3Ddetail
<http://sourceforge.net/tracker/=
index.php?func=3Ddetail&aid=3D1208290&group_id=3D7
3833&atid=3D539102> &aid=
=3D1208290&group_id=3D73833&atid=3D539102
 
>
>> URI reg.expr filter (OR ba=
sed) that has a list of strings instead of just
>> one.
>> 
>> I find mysel=
f using a series of URI reg.expr. filters to tackle numerous
>> issues. I w=
as thinking that it might be useful to add a similar filter
>> that
>> cont=
ained a list of strings. This would make it a lot easier to add
>> addition=
al filters while a crawl is in progress. I can handle this if you
>> agree =
it's a good idea.
>
>Good idea; perhaps make RFE and assign to yourself? Fo=
r anywhere a Filter
>would be considered, a DecideRule (or pair, for the 'm=
atches' and
'not-matches'
>senses) makes sense too now. 
 
http://sourcefor=
ge.net/tracker/index.php?func=3Ddetail
<http://sourceforge.net/tracker/inde=
x.php?func=3Ddetail&aid=3D1208293&group_id=3D7
3833&atid=3D539102> &aid=3D1=
208293&group_id=3D73833&atid=3D539102
 
>
>> In help (and perhaps a link fr=
om the logs) provide a quick link to the
>> result codes (local, not on web=
).
>> 
>> I find myself looking these up a lot. Having a handy, local refer=
ence
>> would
>> be useful. Should include both the HTTP codes and the ones=
 specified by
>> Heritrix.
>
>Definitely, please add at your convenience. 
=
 
Will do.
 
<snip>
 
Since there are bugs/RFEs for the rest, I'll direct a=
ny further
thoughts/replies there.
 
- Kris
